turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Sleep all right?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Yes, thanks.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Good. More coffee?  Robert, I hope you don't mind my asking, but I feel like I should.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Well, these... women friends of yours... all over the world. How does it work? Do you see some of them again? Do you forget others? Do you write them now and then? How do you manage it?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I... What do you want?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Well, I just want to know the procedure. I don't want to upset your routine. Do you want any jam?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Routine! I don't have a routine. And if you think that's what this is -

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Well, what is this?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Well, why is that up to me? You're the one who's married. You told me you have no intention of leaving your husband.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: To do what? Be with someone who needs everyone and no one in particular? I mean, what would be the point. Would you pass the butter?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I was honest with you. I told you who I was.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Yes. Absolutely. You have this habit of not needing and that it's hard to break. I understand.  Of course, in that case, why sleep -- you don't need rest or for that matter eat, you don't need food.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Gee, I don't know. I guess I'm not cut out to be a World Citizen who experiences everything and nothing at the same time.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: How do you know what I experience?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I know you! What can this possibly mean to anyone who doesn't "need" meaning -  "Who goes with the Mystery" -- who pretends he isn't scared to death.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Stop it!

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: You have no idea what you've done to me, do you? And after you leave, I'm going to have to wonder for the rest of my life what happened here. If anything happened at all! And I'll have to wonder if you find yourself in some... housewife's kitchen in Romania if you'll sit there and tell her about your world of good friends and secretly include me in that group.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What do you want me to say?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I don't want you to say anything. I don't need you to say anything.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: STOP IT!

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Fine. More eggs or should we just fuck on the linoleum one last time?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I told you! I won't apologize for who I am.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No one's asking you to!

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I won't be made to feel like I've done something wrong.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: You won't be made to feel! Period. You've carved out this little part for yourself in the world where you get to be a voyeur, a hermit and a lover whenever you feel like it and the rest of us are just supposed to feel so incredibly grateful for the brief time you've touched our lives! Well, go to hell! It isn't human not to feel lonely -- it isn't human not to afraid! You're a hypocrite and you're a phony!

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I DON'T WANT TO NEED YOU!

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: WHY?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: BECAUSE I CAN'T HAVE YOU!

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: WHAT DOES THAT HAVE TO DO WITH IT?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: If I've done anything to make you think that what's happened between us is nothing new for me -- is some routine -- then I do apologize.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: What makes it different, Robert?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No matter how I keep turning it around in my mind -- it doesn't seem like the right thing.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: For who?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: For anyone. They'll never be able to live through the talk. Richard will never be able to. He doesn't deserve that. He hasn't hurt anyone in his life.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Then he can move! People move!

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: His family's lived for almost a hundred years. Richard doesn't know how to live anywhere else. And the kids...

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: The kids are grown! They don't need you anymore. You told me that. They hardly talk to you.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No, they don't say much. But Carolyn's 16. She's just about to find out about all this for herself -- she's going to fall in love, she's going to try and figure out how to build a life with someone. If I leave what does that say to her?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What about us? What about me?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: You've got to know deep down that the minute we leave here. It'll all change.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Yeah. It could get better.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No matter how much distance we put between us and this house, I bring with it with me. And I'll feel it every minute we're together. And I'll blame loving you for how much it hurts. And then even these four days won't be anything more than something sordid and... a mistake.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Francesca, listen to me. You think what's happened to us happens to just anybody? What we feel for each other? How much we feel? We're not even two separate people anymore. Some people search their whole lives for it and wind up alone -- most people don't even think it exists and you're going to tell me that giving it up is the right thing to do? That staying here alone in a marriage, alone in a town you hate, in a house you don't feel apart of anymore -- you're telling me that's the right thing to do!?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: We are the choices we've made, Robert.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: TO HELL WITH YOU!

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Robert. Please.  You don't understand -- no one does. When a woman makes the choice to marry, to have children -- in one way her life begins but in another way it stops. You build a life of details. You become a mother, a wife and you stop and stay steady so that your children can move. And when they leave they take your life of details with them. And then you're expected move again only you don't remember what moves you because no one has asked in so long. Not even yourself. You never in your life think that love like this can happen to you.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: But now that you have it -

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I want to keep it forever. I want to love you the way I do now the rest of my life. Don't you understand -- we'll lose it if we leave. I can't make an entire life disappear to start a new one. All I can do is try to hold onto to both. Help me. Help me not lose loving you.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I don't know. Please...

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'm going to be here a few more days. I'll be at the Inn. We have some time. Let's not say any more now.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: No. Don't do this.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I CAN'T SAY GOODBYE YET! We'll leave it for now. We're not saying goodbye. We're not making any decision. Maybe you'll change your mind. Maybe we'll accidentally run into each other and ... and you'll change your mind.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Robert, if that happens, you'll have to decide. I won't be able to.

turns.speaker: REPORTER
turns.text: Mrs. Johnson! Mrs. Johnson! Is it true Cary Grant has proposed to you?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Yes. And I've accepted.

turns.speaker: REPORTER
turns.text: What about his engagement to Dyan Cannon?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I said to him Cary you're being ridiculous. You're more than half her age. He said no one had ever been that honest with him and he falls in love with me.

turns.speaker: REPORTER
turns.text: What about your husband?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I'm very sad but Richard said that since it's Cary Grant, he completely understands. I'm also taking Mrs. Delaney away from this town. She'll be living with Cary and I in Beverly Hills.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: You feeling better Franny?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Yes. I'm fine. It's just this heat I think.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: It's a Chicago station. I found it the other day.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Kinda pretty. Is this uh... jazz kinda singing?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I don't know. Can we turn it off? I have such a headache.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: 'Bout 4:30.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Well you should all go to bed early. I'll do the cleaning up.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: What time is it?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Later. Go back to sleep.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Where you going?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I'm not tired. I thought I might finish Carolyn's skirt.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Now?!  It's after eleven.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I can't sleep.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Again? Maybe you should see a doctor.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I'm not sick, Richard. I'm just not tired, now go back to sleep before you're up for the whole night too!

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: "I had forgotten this. I had somehow remembered it being more his fault, his decision. Then I remembered we made love in that field before we left for home. And I remembered it was my idea. I remembered tearing his shirt and biting his body, hoping he would kidnap me. I had forgotten that too. And I wondered, as I sat there... how many other things I'd forgotten."

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Frannie.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: I'm positive.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: I'm going to miss you.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: It's only four days.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Want anything special for dinner?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Hmm. How about that brown sugar meat loaf you make?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Franny?

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Hmm?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: I just want to say... I know you had your own dreams. I'm sorry I couldn't give them to you. I love you so much.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Are you seeing Betty tonight?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Nah.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: What's her name?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Betty.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: What's she like?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Uh... Yeah. Yeah. She's real nice.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Well, what's nice about her? Tell us!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Well, she's... she's real pretty and ... and she's got a cute shape... she's a good sport, ya know, for laughs and  ... she loves fried chicken wings and beer.

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Isn't that nice? You should bring her home to meet us!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Oh my God...!

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I was paying the check. She ran outside. I told her to wait for me right here! Oh God, where is she? Rebecca!

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Think for a second. Is there someplace she said she wanted to go?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I don't remember!

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: About an hour ago.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: They're not going to find her!

turns.speaker: FRANCESCA
turns.text: Yes, they are.

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: Your mother left explicit instructions that she wished to be cremated.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Cremated?!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: When did she decide this?

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: Apparently just before her death.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Well, that's crazy. I don't know anybody who gets cremated.

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: It clearly states in the will --

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I don't care what it says! Maybe Mama was delirious, you know. She didn't know what she was saying. If she wanted to be cremated, why the hell did she let dad buy two plots, huh?

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: Well, she was very specific. She wanted her ashes to be thrown over Roseman Bridge.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: WHAT!

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: Well, it was notarized, and witnessed by a Mrs. Lucy Delaney. Maybe you can ask her.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Who the hell is Lucy Delaney?

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Don't feed that dog.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You people really don't like dogs.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Some holes can't be filled.  Some hungers can't be satisfied.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Outta my way, boy.  Cinnabar?  I'm coming!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Why don't you hang on and I'll see if she's here.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: I know damn well she's there.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: We can't go back there.  Are you crazy? You saw --

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: It's the only way.  It's possible your father may not be dead yet.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Your father was his best friend.  He loved Jeremiah.  So he must hate him the most of all now.  He'll take his time. But even if it is too late.  If your father is dead.  It's not over.  The door has to be closed.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, close the fucking door by all means.  But don't expect me to go down there and do it.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: I don't.

turns.speaker: SHOTGUN
turns.text: Hey, watcha doing with that dog?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: He yours, sir?

turns.speaker: SHOTGUN
turns.text: Hell no!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Then what do you care?

turns.speaker: SHOTGUN
turns.text: Take my advice.  And shoot that dog.  Or let me.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Alright.  Yes sir.  Anything you say.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Is it true?

turns.speaker: SHOTGUN
turns.text: Yeah.  He lived there.  And died there, too.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Died there?  How?

turns.speaker: SHOTGUN
turns.text: How the hell should I know?

turns.speaker: SHOTGUN
turns.text: Hey, kid.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: SHOTGUN
turns.text: Take my advice.  Get the hell out of there.  It's a bad place.  Always has been.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: We practically paying him for the privilege of playing his club.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: So what the hell's the good news?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Bones!  How baddass is zat?  This is the place for us.  Patrick, you get platinum props, man.  Platinum.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Yeah, in the land of the blind the one eye'd are king.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What's your problem with Crippled Dick?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Look around, this place is a dump!  Naw, it'd have to work to be a dump.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Are you nuts?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: The man said just to use my imagination.  Let's see...yeah, I get it.  Potential. I can see it now.  The first major urban theme park.  Village Ghetto land. Kinda like Legoland, but made entirely from broken glass, hypodermic needles and crack vials.  Totally E-ticket.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Keep smokin', fool.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You didn't hear that?  "Take him... " Something.  "Bury him" or...

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Take who where?  What you smokin'?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: 'S up?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Nothing.  Contact paranoia.  Must be buggin' from hanging with you.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Ugh.  Muchos moscos, man.  This is too much.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Just some flies.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Some flies?  I think this qualifies as way more than "some."

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Oh yeah, I guess this would be that space that was so perfect for a recording studio.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Maurice, man, shut the fuck up.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Boys and girls, Moms and Dads.  Children of all ages, I'd like you to meet... Jimmy Bones.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What the hell you talking about?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: "This is the story of Jimmy Bones/Black as night and hard as stones/Gold plated deuce, like the King of Siam/Got his switchblade loose, and a diamond on his hand..." There's the switchblade and there's the diamond.  Don't know where the deuce is parked.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You think that's really him?

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Damn.  It's so...fresh.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: ...Bones ol' Bones so mean and bad, whupped his mamma, shot his dad.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Saw Bones ol' Bones on top of the hill. Rolling fat jays outta hundred dollar bills.

turns.speaker: MAURICE
turns.text: Can you take a little extended solo right about now, funk soul brotha?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Go for it.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Looks like a damn graveyard round here.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: I'm telling you, this neighborhood is coming back.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Damn.  That is the ugliest building I have ever seen.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Naw.  I think it's... I dunno.  Something about it just buzzes me.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You want us to move in here?

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: That's the only way we'll get the place fixed up in time.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You soundin' like the old man now.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: I believe in you guys.  You are the real shit.  And you know it.  Now I'm putting everything I got into this cuz I think we can make it happen, but you gotta put a little in too.  Now all I"m asking is that everybody do their part.  We'll move some shit in, and take shifts, or all crash together here --

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Pat's right.  It'll be fun.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Tia ain't a chick.  She's family.  And don't forget it.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Let's get going.  Go home, pick up what we need, then crash here.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Shit.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Spooked?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: No.  Well, yeah.  Maybe just a little.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Yeah, there is a strange vibe here.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Where's the others?

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Maurice left.  Tia's taking a bath.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Yeah, we can.  Least till after this weekend.  He ain't going nowhere.  We'll deal with it then.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Whatever, let's just get the hellout of here.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You sure got a way with women, bro.  What happened up there?

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Damned if I know.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Where's the gangsta of love?

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Probably stoned out of his gourd in some corner.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, go find his lazy ass.  I scratch any more tonight I'm gonna have carpal tunnel syndrome.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: You ain't going down there.  Not alone. I'll go.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Fine.  But I'm bringing a couple of friends.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: We can climb out.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Climb out to where?

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Anywhere but here.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Is this Hell?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Or just Hell-adjacent...

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: Don't poison your mind with that ghetto paranoia.  That's all just ways of people justifying their own failure.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Dad, the man has been lying to us for a hundred years.  I mean, where is my forty acres and a mule?

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: You wouldn't know a mule if it bit you in the ass. And personally, I don't need a mule.  I got a Lexus.  And nobody gave it to me --

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: That's what?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: That's some terrible shit.

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: Clean your mouth, or I will.  Those boys had no business messing down there.  Go places you're not meant to be -- that's what you get.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: But that's your old hood, Pops.

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: Yeah, and it took some doing to get out of there.  Just be glad I did and you can start life from here instead of down there.

turns.speaker: STANK
turns.text: Looking to score?

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Unh-unh, little brother.  I got a natural high.  A supernatural high.

turns.speaker: STANK
turns.text: Hey, Eddie Mack don't like no wackos on his street.  Go be Rain Man on some other bitch's block.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Big Bad Eddie Mack?  Got shit for brains and that's a fack.  Hey-heh...

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: You tell my old friend Mackie, I'll be seeing him.  Soon.  Real soon.

turns.speaker: STANK
turns.text: Wh-wh-whooo?

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Bones.

turns.speaker: MACK
turns.text: Yeah, we used to do the after-school b ball at Kenwood.  What it is?

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: What it will be.

turns.speaker: MACK
turns.text: You got a nice crib here.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: I do alright.  Everybody's happy.

turns.speaker: MACK
turns.text: But things change.  You gotta think ahead.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: What else?  Money.

turns.speaker: MACK
turns.text: It ain't the money - it's the high.  The big fat floating 'what if?'  And it's way more profitable.  Nobody ever wins.  So you never have to pay out.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: But a two dollar bet is cheaper than a twenty-dollar bag.

turns.speaker: MACK
turns.text: Yeah, but I ain't talking horse.  I'm talking about a five-dollar kick in the head that's a quick ticket to heaven. And the fools keep coming back for more.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Those 'fools' are my people.

turns.speaker: MACK
turns.text: Ain't no big thang.  It's just a po' man's free base.  Here, check it out.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: I ain't interested.  And if you gonna sell it, don't sell it round here.

turns.speaker: MACK
turns.text: Just try it.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: I said, no thanks.

turns.speaker: MACK
turns.text: Go on.  It won't kill you.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Maybe I oughtta get there a little early. For good luck.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Don't need luck tonight.  I'm just letting 'em have their say before I say no.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Let me see your hand.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: All that shinin' and "reader and adviser" mess.  That was your mama's bag.  I don't know about the readin' but you both can sure 'nuff advise.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: My mama's bag and my granma's bag, and a long line of mamas before her.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Sounds like mama needs a brand new bag.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Left hand's the past.  Your right's the present.  And the future.  But it's not written in stone.  It's written in flesh and blood.  And flesh and blood will change.  See?  There's something here, a new line, right across your life line.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Must be my clothes line.  No?  How bout my phone line?

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: No baby.  I'm serious.  Cancel that meeting.  I got more fruit that needs checking.  Come home with me now.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Don't you worry about a thing.  This hand's gonna be stroking the back of your neck tonight.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Gotta be an in-ey and gotta be smooth. If it's ragged, it was picked too soon. Won't ever be ripe.  Second, it's got to have just a little give, here.  At the edges.  And last, but not very far from least...  You gotta get your nose in it and give it a gooooood, looooong sniff.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: I don't know whether to chill you and serve with cottage cheese, or rip you open and eat you right here.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: No?  That mean there's something more left of you than just that hungry spirit? What are you going to do now?  Kill us? Kill us all?

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: No.  Not...not you.  You I forgive.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Jimmy, you've got --

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: I've got what I want.  Turn around baby, look at me.  Look at your man.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: I want you to do something for me, baby.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Where are we, baby?

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Where we'll always be...

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: But.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Hush, baby.

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: 'Sup Jimmy B. Shotgun.  Get back on the curb!  Now!

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Go easy on Jay Bird.  I can remember when we was his age...

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: It's all arranged for tonight.  Eddie Mack's gonna be there.  And Offisa Korruptsky, too.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: They get about twelve and a half minutes. Tops.

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: Trust me, Jimmy, there's big money behind this.  Not just big.  BIG.  Like big business big.  Big corporation big.  Big government big.  Our little acre alone'll net hundreds a thousands.  Nothing but net.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Nothing but net?  Could be a swish.  Or a muthafucking air ball.

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: One simple word, three little letters. Yes.  That's all it's gonna take and we could move out of this dump, get the real deal.  Big houses, legit business...

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: That's your dream, Homes.  Not mine.  I don't want to leave this street.  Ever. The status quo is totally cool with me.

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: Hey Jimmy, you know Eddie Mack, don't you?

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: We met.

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: Everybody just be cool.  Jimmy, man, I think you oughtta hear the deal.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: I don't need to hear the deal.  I don't need any partners.  I don't need new product.  And I sure as hell don't need this motherfucker's 'mattie in my face.

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: Sorry, my brother.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Since we was just grasshoppers...

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: You always told me, it's a dog eat dog world.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: What it will be.

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: How did you get in here?

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Time like this, is that what you really want to know?  How I got the fuck in here?

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: I don't understand it.  You were my Man. Since we was grasshoppas.  I always looked after you.  You had a piece of everything I had.

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: I didn't want a piece of yours, I wanted my own.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: And the hell everybody else, right?

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: Wait, Jimmy.  Think about it.  You woulda done the same thing if you was me.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: No brother.  I wouldn'ta.  I never done a man - any man.  Let alone a brother like that.  Course, as you can see, no good deed goes unfucked.  Now the question is, if the good get fucked, what we got saved up for the bad?  You about to find out.

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: What will it take?  What do you want? Just tell me, Jimmy!

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Aw that's easy.  I want my life back. Can you swing that, my brother?

turns.speaker: JEREMIAH
turns.text: You know I can't.

turns.speaker: BONES
turns.text: Then fuck it!!!

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Aren't you going to join us?

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: I have to finish this for class.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: You got a vision, girl.  Just like I got. Just like my momma had.  And the good Lord didn't give you that vision just for painting pretty pictures.  That's just wasted time.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: You mean as opposed to your life?

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: I'm sorry, Momma.  Maybe next time.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: I don't want you meeting around that house.  You stay away from those kids. And away from that dog.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: They seemed alright.  Bring a little life to that old building.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Nothing but a wide world o' pain locked in there.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Have you ever been inside?

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Maybe once upon a time.  But that was long ago.  Back before... before it became what it is.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: And what's that?

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Just a bad place.  And the doorway to worse.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: ...I've seen things.  In there.  Last night.  You did too.  Don't tell me you didn't.  You were crying like a baby.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: You said the vision, the images.  They're just that.  Just pictures.  They can't hurt you.  That's what you always said.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: I lied.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: All the more reason I should be here.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Please.  It's for your own good.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: You said bad things hurt places.  So maybe good things heal them.  Good things are happening here.  Maybe for the first time ever.  And maybe that's all it takes.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: It's alright, baby.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Who was he, Momma?  He tried to kill us.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: If he was trying to kill you, you'd be dead.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Who?  Who is he?  What is he?

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Your father.  He was your father.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: You got his hands.  Beautiful hands.  I didn't even know.  That night.  When they - we - killed him, that you were already alive inside me.  Life's like that. Grows right out of death.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: But if it's him.  If he's really come back, won't he know us?  Love us?

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Sure, if it was really him.  But it isn't that simple.  Jimmy's body died a long time ago.  And his soul is long gone, and all that's left is that ravening, hungry spirit in the blood that soaked into the house itself, I suppose.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: But how do you know?  Maybe he just wanted to see us?  And now he's gone again.  And you've all killed my father for the second time.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: He'll kill them.  He'll kill every last one of them.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Eddie Mack, that cop.  And Jeremiah.  And even when he's done, who knows.  He won't be satisfied.  Just like that demon dog. Feed it, and it just grows hungrier. Feed his hunger for revenge - he just wants more.  Who knows where it'll stop. That kind of hunger ain't never satisfied.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Aren't you gonna do something about it?

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Like what?  I got a little power, sure. A touch of the shining, a little of the sight.  But no more than you do.  We're not witches.  I can't wiggle my nose or say a magic word and make him go away. Besides, maybe they deserve it.  Maybe we all do.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: I don't.  Patrick doesn't.  And his brother and sister don't.  And they're in the house with him.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Fine.  Maybe I got nothing to lose. 'Cept you.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: We'll have to sneak in.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: No we won't, Momma.  I'll just have them call and tell Patrick it's us.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Girl, they build gates like that to keep people like us out.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: Told you so.  Alright.  We tried.  Let's go home.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Mother!  No.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: In his grave there was a cloth or a dress or something.  Covered with blood.

turns.speaker: PEARL
turns.text: My God.  My dress.  We have to find it. And burn it.  And shut the door.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: no really, let us help.  We're new in the neighborhood, gonna be neighbors.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: You moved into this block?

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Are they on the radio?

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Naw.  But they will be.  They're the best.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: I manage them.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Guess it's not Rossmore Park.  Thanks for the help.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Anytime.  Be seeing you.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Careful.  That's bad luck.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: That place is already bad luck.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: No.  It goes way back.  Or so my Momma says.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: What else does she say?

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Nothing.  You'd think she was crazy.  And she is a lot of things, not all of them nice, but crazy Momma's not.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Way I figure, everything our parents tell us is part true and part total B.S.  And our whole job is figuring out for ourselves which is which.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: My momma says every house is two houses. Every street, two streets.  There's a whole city, a whole world, kinda beside, on top, just below this one.  The city of the dead.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Like right now, there's actually like hordes of dead people shambling around us?  Fingers rotting off?

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Maybe.  But there's an invisible wall, a fabric that kinda keeps things separate.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Lucky thing.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Yeah.  But when something bad happens, something really bad -- the wall breaks. The fabric tears.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: The dead get out?

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Or the living fall in.  Who knows.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: And you believe her?

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: If I did, I wouldn't come within fifty yards of your door.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Cinn?

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: What?  Oh yeah.  Coming.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: She doesn't want me here.  With you.  In this house.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Believe me, my old man'd rupture his spleen if he knew we was down here.  All he talks about is the medal he deserves for building us a life as far from this 'hood as possible.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: He probably thinks he's saving you from something.  I'm sure that's what my mother thinks.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: I'm sure I can make your mother like me. But then do I gotta worry 'bout your father?

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: I can't.  Not yet.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: It's alright.  If you want to go home...

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: No, I want to stay with you guys.  But I can't.  I mean I'm not ready.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Don't worry about it.  I'll stay with the boys.

turns.speaker: CINNABAR
turns.text: Why couldn't you just tell him to let us in?

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: My old man calls the shots.  He built that gate and these damn walls.
